interventions.Title: Cognitive Restructuring
interventions.Description:
'- **Why it Helps:** It addresses distorted beliefs and thoughts that lead to excessive internet use.
   - **What to Do:** Identify negative thoughts about internet use (e.g., "I need to be online to be happy"), challenge them, and replace them with healthier beliefs.
   - **Example:** If you think, "Only online can I connect with people," challenge this by recalling positive offline interactions and try to balance your social activities.
interventions.extracted_value:
Describe the situation that led to your negative emotions or thoughts.
What happened?
Where were you?
Who was involved?
How did you feel in the moment?
Write down the immediate thoughts that came to mind when the situation occurred. These are often negative, irrational, or distorted.
What were you thinking?
What meaning did you attach to the situation?
Examine the validity of your automatic thoughts.
Is there another way to look at this situation?
Are there any facts that contradict my negative thoughts?
Write down a healthier way of thinking.
What is a more balanced and rational alternative to my negative thoughts?
How can I reframe this situation positively?
Create a list of affirmations or positive statements to reinforce your new, balanced thoughts.
What positive statements can I use to remind myself of my healthier beliefs?
Identify actions you can take to support your new thinking.
What steps can I take to avoid falling into the same negative thought patterns in the future?
How can I incorporate healthier behaviors into my daily routine?

interventions.Title: Behavioral Activation
interventions.Description:
'- **Why it Helps:** Encourages engagement in meaningful activities outside of the internet.
   - **What to Do:** Schedule and commit to offline activities that you enjoy or find rewarding (e.g., exercise, hobbies).
   - **Example:** Plan to go for a walk with a friend every day instead of spending that time on social media.
interventions.extracted_value:
Daily Activities
What activities did I do today?


How did these activities make me feel?


Were there any activities I avoided today? If so, why?


Scheduled Activities
What activities am I planning to do tomorrow?


Why are these activities important to me?


Are there any potential obstacles to completing these activities? If so, how can I overcome them?


Reflection
Did I engage in any activities that brought me joy or satisfaction today?


What did I learn about myself and my behaviors today?


Are there any changes I need to make to my schedule or activities to better support my mental health?

interventions.Title: Time Management
interventions.Description:
'- **Why it Helps:** Helps to control and reduce the time spent online.
   - **What to Do:** Set specific limits for internet use each day and adhere to these limits. Use tools like time blockers.
   - **Example:** Allocate 1 hour in the evening for internet use, and engage in offline activities during other times.
interventions.extracted_value:
Daily Goals
What are my top 3 goals for today?
Why are these goals important to me?
Time Allocation
How many hours do I plan to spend online today?
What specific times will I use the internet?
What offline activities will I engage in during other times?
Task List
What tasks need to be completed today?
How much time will each task require?
What resources or tools do I need to complete each task?
Progress Tracking
How am I progressing with my tasks?
Are there any tasks that are taking longer than expected?
What adjustments can I make to stay on track?
Reflection
Did I stay within my allocated internet time?
Were there any challenges or obstacles?
What can I do differently tomorrow to improve my time management?

interventions.Title: Mindfulness and Grounding Techniques
interventions.Description:
'- **Why it Helps:** Increases awareness of present moments, reduces compulsive behaviors.
   - **What to Do:** Practice mindfulness exercises to become more aware of the urges to go online and decide more consciously if you want to connect.
   - **Example:** When you feel the urge to check your phone, take a deep breath and note how your body feels instead.
interventions.extracted_value:
YYYY-MM-DD
Mindfulness and Grounding Techniques
5-4-3-2-1 Method
What are five things you can see around you?
What are four things you can touch?
What are three things you can hear?
What are two things you can smell?
What is one emotion you feel?
Breathing Deeply
How does your body feel when you breathe deeply?
Do you notice any changes in your breathing pattern?
Savoring a Food or Drink
What food or drink did you choose to savor?
How did it taste and smell?
Did you notice any specific flavors or textures?
Putting Hands in Water
What temperature water did you use?
How did the water feel on your fingertips, palms, and the backs of your hands?
Did you notice any differences in sensation when switching between warm and cold water?

interventions.Title: Exposure and Response Prevention
interventions.Description:
'- **Why it Helps:** Gradually reduces anxiety about being offline.
   - **What to Do:** Gradually increase the amount of time spent offline in situations where you typically feel the need to go online.
   - **Example:** Start by staying offline for 15 minutes longer each day during a typically high-use time.
interventions.extracted_value:
What situation did I face today?


How anxious did I feel during this situation?


Did I resist the urge to go online? If so, how?


How did I feel after resisting the urge to go online?


What did I learn from this experience?


How can I apply this experience to future situations?


Are there any challenges I faced during this exercise? If so, how can I overcome them?


What steps can I take to continue making progress in reducing my anxiety about being offline?

interventions.Title: Setting Realistic Goals
interventions.Description:
'- **Why it Helps:** Provides attainable objectives to reduce internet dependence.
   - **What to Do:** Set specific, measurable goals for internet use that can be re-evaluated and adjusted regularly.
   - **Example:** Aim to reduce daily internet use by 30 minutes each week until you reach a 2-hour per day limit.
interventions.extracted_value:
What are your current internet usage habits?


What specific, measurable goals do you want to set for reducing your internet use?


How will you track your progress towards these goals?


What challenges might you face in achieving these goals, and how will you overcome them?


How will you adjust your goals if you find them too easy or too difficult to achieve?

interventions.Title: Self-Monitoring
interventions.Description:
'- **Why it Helps:** Increases self-awareness about patterns and triggers for internet use.
   - **What to Do:** Keep a journal of your internet use, including when, where, and why you went online.
   - **Example:** Note every time you use your phone and the activity you're engaged in to identify triggers.

interventions.Title: Challenge Automatic Thoughts
interventions.Description:
'- **Why it Helps:** Reduces automatic thoughts contributing to internet overuse.
   - **What to Do:** Whenever you notice automatic thoughts about needing to be online, pause and evaluate their validity.
   - **Example:** Transform "I’ll miss out if I’m not online" to "It’s okay to take breaks; I can catch up later."
interventions.extracted_value:
Describe the situation or trigger that led to the automatic thought.
What was your initial response to the trigger?


What is the negative automatic thought that came up?


What evidence supports this thought?


What evidence opposes this thought?


What is a more realistic or helpful way of thinking about this situation?


How did challenging this thought affect your emotions and reactions?

interventions.Title: Problem-Solving Skills
interventions.Description:
'- **Why it Helps:** Develops alternative strategies to cope with life pressures that lead to internet overuse.
   - **What to Do:** Identify problems that lead you to use the internet excessively and brainstorm solutions.
   - **Example:** If feeling lonely leads to internet use, plan to join an offline group or club.
interventions.extracted_value:
What are the specific situations that lead me to use the internet excessively?
How do these situations make me feel?
What are the negative consequences of excessive internet use in these situations?
What alternative strategies can I use to cope with these situations?
What are some offline activities I can engage in to reduce internet use?
How can I make these alternative strategies more appealing and accessible?
Which of the alternative strategies I brainstormed seem most effective?
What are the potential benefits and drawbacks of each strategy?
How can I implement and maintain these strategies in my daily life?
What specific steps will I take to implement my chosen strategy?
How will I track my progress and stay motivated?
What potential obstacles might arise, and how will I overcome them?

interventions.Title: Developing New Coping Strategies
interventions.Description:
'- **Why it Helps:** Creates new pathways to deal with emotions instead of turning to the internet.
    - **What to Do:** Develop a list of offline coping strategies for negative emotions, like stress or boredom.
    - **Example:** Instead of using the internet for distraction, practice deep breathing or exercise when stressed.

By applying these CBT strategies, individuals can reduce their dependence on the internet, leading to a healthier balance in their daily lives.
